Law of Composition

A law of composition on a set $M$ is a map from $M \times M$ to $M$. It is characterized by the assignment $(a, b) \longmapsto a \cdot b$ for $(a, b) \in M \times M$, and in many cases, the image of a given pair $(a, b)$ is written as a "product" $a \cdot b$ or $ab$.
Cyclic group
A group $G$ is called cyclic if it is generated by a single element. This is equivalent to the existence of a surjective group homomorphism $\mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow G$.
Zero Ring
The zero ring is a ring where the unit element of addition (0) and the unit element of multiplication (1) are the same, i.e., 1=0. It consists of a single element 0.
Ring Epimorphism
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an epimorphism if it is surjective.
Greatest common divisor

An element $d \in R$ is called a greatest common divisor of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $d \mid x_{i}$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $d$ is a common divisor of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common divisor of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $a \mid x_{i}$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $a \mid d$.
Field of Fractions

For an integral domain $R$, the field of fractions $Q(R)$ is the set of equivalence classes of pairs $(a, b)$ where $a, b \in R$ and $b \neq 0$, under the equivalence relation defined by $(a, b) \sim (a', b')$ if and only if $ab' = a'b$.
Characteristic of a field

Let $K$ be a field (or, more generally, an integral domain) and let $\varphi: \mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow K$ be the canonical ring homomorphism. Furthermore, let $p \in \mathbb{N}$ be a generating element of the principal ideal $\operatorname{ker} \varphi$. Then $p$ is called the characteristic of $K$, and we write $p=\operatorname{char} K$.
Finitely Generated Field Extension
A field extension $K \subset L$ is called finitely generated if there exist finitely many elements $\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n} \in L$ such that $L=K(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n})$.
Splitting field of Family of Polynomials

A splitting field of a family of nonconstant polynomials \\(\mathfrak{F}=(f_i)_{i \in I}, f_i \in K[X]\\) over a field \\(K\\) is a field \\(L\\) extending \\(K\\) such that: (i) Every polynomial \\(f_i\\) decomposes into a product of linear factors over \\(L\\). (ii) The extension \\(L / K\\) is generated by the zeros of the polynomials \\(f_i\\).
Galois extension
An extension $K_{r} / K$ is Galois if it is both normal and separable.
Cycle

A permutation $\pi \in \mathfrak{S}_{n}$ is called a cycle if there exist distinct elements $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}$ in $\{1, \ldots, n\}, r \geq 2$, such that $\pi(x_{i}) = x_{i+1}$ for $1 \leq i < r$, $\pi(x_{r}) = x_{1}$, and $\pi(x) = x$ for $x \in \{1, \ldots, n\} - \{x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\}$.
Map/Function
A map is a relationship between two sets that associates every element in one set(domain) to exactly one element in another set (codomain).
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A law of composition is defined as a map from M x M to M. Therefore, the concept of a map/function must be defined to understand what a law of composition is.

A cyclic group is defined as a group generated by a single element. The concept of a group is inherently dependent on the law of composition, as a group is a set equipped with a law of composition that satisfies certain axioms.

A ring epimorphism is a specific type of ring homomorphism, which is a map between two rings that preserves the ring operations. Therefore, the concept of a map/function must be defined to understand what a ring epimorphism is.
The field of fractions is defined for an integral domain. Therefore, the concept of an integral domain must be defined to understand what a field of fractions is.

The characteristic of a field is defined using a canonical ring homomorphism from the integers to the field. Therefore, the concept of a map/function must be defined to understand what the characteristic of a field is.

A splitting field of a family of polynomials is defined as a field extension such that every polynomial in the family decomposes into linear factors over the field. Therefore, the concept of a field extension must be defined to understand what a splitting field is.
A Galois extension is defined as an extension that is both normal and separable. Therefore, the concept of a field extension must be defined to understand what a Galois extension is.
